After playing it a bunch, I can't say any interesting play emerges. I can think of a ton of simple games that get way more intense after playing them a lot, while this just stays exactly the same. While still being too meek and time-consuming to be a wild gambling game. Like my first thoughts are Hols der Geier and No Thanks, those are much more exciting than this. It's fine, nothing more.

This game is ridiculous! There is absolutely no way to plan for anything. To prove it, I played a game by putting my cards in a pile face down and played the top card every turn. And I won!!! Will not play again. Rivals Xactica and Phase 10 in being the worst card game I've ever played.
It's just a slot machine. No skill involved here. Probably one of the worst card games I have ever played.

Even when it’s other players being punished, I don’t find myself enjoying the game… I just feel a moment of relief that it wasn’t me.

1) Select the proper card that makes you avoid taking rows of cards while forcing your opponents to do just that.
2) Every turn, players select a card from their hand they wish to play in secret. Cards are revealed together and arranged in ascending order, then added to one of 4 rows. Once a row is full, the person who played the last card in it takes it and scores all of the points on the cards that were in it. A couple more wrinkles complete the ruleset, with the game ending after the round a player has accrued enough points. Player with the lowest points wins.
3) I loved: Much more tense than No Thanks!, there are multiple ways to think about the cards you have. Cards in hand can be good or bad depending on the situation, and sometimes playing a bad card to come away with 1 point only is not a bad play. Looking in horror as, after waiting for the last round to play a card, a row is taken and suddenly you find that card completing another row!
4) Could be improved: Really needs a fixed group to evolve the groupthink and to guess and outguess each other. When played with a new group every time, it may seem a bit random. On the other hand it is not the type of game I wish to play repeatedly to really develop that groupthink or to really get good at for that matter.
5) A great filler for large groups, more involved than No Thanks! but in that ballpark. Likely still prefer LLAMA.

This game is super random. There is basically no strategy that you can employ that would help you take less points. I don't hate the game but, I also don't love the game either. It's a fun play the game for a couple of rounds every couple of months but, I wouldn't play more than that.

Acceptable filler. I was taught the wrong rules, so I haven't yet played this with the correct rules.

After a few games on BGA: A very simple game that allows a surprisingly high player count. It’s very luck-driven, yet still offers enough suspense to keep you engaged. It serves a similar purpose to the much newer Flip 7, but gives you more to think about in comparison. I have the strange feeling that I haven’t yet fully grasped its tactics. And somehow it annoys me to get penalty points. It makes me feel stupid. And I feel increasingly little motivation to go through these numbers in my head and optimize my move. The theme – an ox – doesn’t appeal to me; I associate it with aggression, hypermasculinity, and animal cruelty, none of which are pleasant.

You play a card face down simultaneously with all other players, and then they are added in chronological order to the row, of several, which has the next lowest number as its rightmost card. If you would add a sixth card to a row, you take the whole row in front of you into your scoring pile. Some cards have more points on than others. Lowest points at the end wins.

I like the concept but I don't think I've had a good game of this. You can play a calculating async game online, but what should run raucous in person has never fully come off, in my experience. I perhaps teach the game too seriously. I've played with a bunch of variants. I like using only the cards matching the number of players, multiplied by 10, plus 4. Other rules seem to complicate the core appeal. The 'professional' variant (you can play a card to either side of a row) becomes a wholly other game, which I can't assess without a lot more plays.

Any version works. The game doesn't look pretty.

I just like to play one round, because 30+ minutes of this feels absurd. It suffers the fate of many classics: too many ways to play. You may find that your preferred rules repulse gamers, and casual players don't care about the game one way or another. I consider it a 4-8 player game. At 4p, I'd place three rows, and have players take a row once the fifth card gets placed, because otherwise the game gets flabby. Or, honestly, play something else.

Another of these elegant German card games, specifically simultaneous card selection reminiscent of Turn the Tide. If it has a problem I think it's the part where a player playing a low card selects a row to take, with all other cards visible. This open calculation - and potentially choosing a player to target - seems at odds with the rest of the game.

The game has a good reputation in many gamer circles, but it's difficult to assess what skills this game asks for. You can probably come up with a strategy based on counting cards. Otherwise you lay down cards and hope for the best. It's not what I would call a social game either.

However, there can be little disagreement on one point that the game as a specific addictive quality to it. I suppose it's something similar to gambling in the sense that one wants to play just ONE more game and see how it turns out. In addition, the game creates a certain kind of tension and relief, which is neat. I also find that it tends to hold peoples attention better than other light card games.

Has a nice combination of trick taking strategy and opportunity cost considerations, a la Lost Cities. Seems like it can be played decent with no sophisticated strategy, but at the same time it rewards strategic thinking as deeply as you care to push it; a great combination. The uncertainty of which cards might be in play reduces the opportunity for analysis paralysis, and helps the game flow.

Note that for 2 players, I took the advice of a bgg post and adapted the rules slightly: only the cards 1-37 are in play; 3 rows instead of 4; 12 cards each; first to 42 cattle points loses.

Small card game (110 cards I think) in a small box. Easy to learn, quit quick to play (4-6 rounds, each about 5-10 minutes long) and pretty strategic. Losing doesn't feel bad, as there is of course a luck element to it. But epic rounds are possible and also teasing the opponent(s). Overall a nice little mix of elements and always fun to play.

Played 4x on BGA. Simple game with interesting decisions about how to best dump your hand without taking points. Players alternate, taking rows that they are forced to fill, or picking a row to take if they cannot throw a card larger than one of the rightmost cards in the rows.
Je mehr Runden man spielt, desto mehr wird der Glücksfaktor eliminiert den eine einzelne Runde mit sich bringt. Eine gute Strategie und richtige Entscheidungen zahlen sich langfristig aus.

Goes over very well in mixed gamer and non-gamer groups, which is important for many of us with different friend/ family groups. Decisions are meaningful, but sometimes you are just burned by luck. The luck somehow feels better than in some highly lucky games. You still feel like you could have chosen differently or more wisely when you hit some back luck. Fun.

Card game

Great double-think, hand management card game that shines with larger groups (5 players, up to 10) and creates lots of laughter.

104 cards (values 1-104), each player gets 10, four are placed face-up to start four rows. Players simultaneously choose a card and reveal it. Starting with the lowest value, then the 2nd lowest, until the highest, cards are added to the rows following two rules: (1) All rows must be in ascending order; (2) a card must be placed into that row where it creates the smallest gap to the previous card of that row. If a card played becomes the sixth card in that row, the player takes the other five as penalty, leaving their card as the new start. If a card is too small for all rows, the player must take one entire row instead, but can choose which one; again the card played starts the new row.

Cards carry 1-7 negative points (mostly 1; values ending in 5 = 2, ending in 0 = 3, doubles = 5, and 55 = 7, as it's ending in 5 and a double). After all cards are played, placed and resolved, scores are tallied. The game ends when someone reaches 66+ points and the lowest score wins. Otherwise, play another round with 10 cards per player.

Excellent easy party game. The fun part is how the game changes with varying number of players.
This might be the only game I keep taking to parties and actually end up playing for years.
un classique !

Wolfgang Kramer , you little (big?) genius. 6 Nimmt! is currently dominating my gaming life. Why? ‘Cause this very unassuming, ugly duckling is fun; loud, sweary fun. There are squeaky bum moments aplenty as you skirt around the edge of disaster, praying that no-one else has the card that will put you ‘over the top’. It’s great to win, but a soul crushing catastrophe if you lose. Why not a 10 then? Well, it’s the gaming equivalent of riding a bucking bronco - you’ll find yourself holding on for dear life but as often as not this bad boy is going to toss you off (and not in a good way).
Addicting.
Most card games feel dry and ho hum to me, but this one is an exception.
Sometimes you run into a small, older game that really sparks your interest. Give this a try if you get a chance. (Board game arena!)
Excellent filler game for 4-10 players. Playing cards at random seems to be almost as effective as attempting some sort of 'strategy'. Good fun and highly recommended.
6 Nimmt is a classic, and one of my favourite card games ever. It's easy to teach, quick, no downtime, and has a great balance of luck, strategy, and reading others.

Simoultaneous play, quick, engaging, and still competitive enough to be enjoyed by everyone. There is more tactics and nuances that may seems at first glance, as involves a clever use of hand management and risk assesment. If you git gud at it you can play the tactics variance to make it more strategic. Extremely portable, easy teach and easy set up. You can adjust the lenght of the game as you can set different goals. The only downside is that requires at least 4 to play.
Escalate quickly from peaceful and friendly to enraging and hilarating, no wonder is a bull the symbol of the game. It's the perfect filler, specially to close the night or inbetween big games. Love it
great game
Complexity √

# 2025-07-16

The digital implementation (BGA) is 10/10. The physical version is lacking because score keeping is tedious if you don't use chips. If you want to use chips, then the game becomes much more difficult to transport.

Additionally, the online version takes care of all the math and row upkeep. This is a huge bonus!

# 2025-07-14

Currently learning heuristics for the game and I personally feel that I enjoy the game much more ever since.

The game feels cryptic at times, but once you get the hang of it, you really feel like you can perform well and learn from your mistakes.

There's definitely a random element to the game, but to me it's not much of an issue because I aim to place in the top 3 (not just 1st!) in 5p games.

I definitely enjoy the game more online right now, and I've only played it once at 4p IRL. I look forward to seeing how it plays at 4-6p IRL.

IRL, the main issue is score keeping. If you use chips or some equivalent, then it's easy. If you use a score tracker or pen-and-paper, then I find it tedious because the host typically has to do all the calculations and accounting.

# 2025-07-10

After playing and winning a few 6p games, I find that winning requires much more adaptive play compared to 5p.

At 5p, I found a reliable strategy that works more often than not, and each game can be played nearly the same way.

At 6p, I must adapt to the current board state at nearly all times. There are definitely more risky moments that feel like a coin flip when compared to 5p games.

Overall I think I like 5p more than 6p, but 6p is still enjoyable.

I prefer to play 6p IF I'm more interested in tense, unpredictable gameplay that requires me to adapt to nearly every situation.

# 2025-07-09

I feel like I prefer 5p much more than 6p. I feel 6p is much more chaotic and unpredictable! HOWEVER, I found that playing your high card liabilities EARLY and then playing safe from then on works well; the go-to strategy at 6p so far.

Extra bonus for being simultaneous play, so games can be relatively short.

Planning to play IRL with a central bank of poker chips. The chips will have different point values, and the players will accumulate them over the course of a game as they gain negative points.

# 2025-07-07

The game is very enjoyable online, and I've yet to play it in person at more than 2P. Currently I enjoy it primarily at 5p.

The score (currently 9) is highly influenced by online play, and it can change in the future depending on how it plays IRL at higher player counts. The main reason it's not easily a 10 is because I have not experienced a great IRL session, only online play.

The game is easy to learn and it's pretty challenging to win (or place high) reliably, especially if you are not "card counting".

The heuristics to win more often are easy to understand and enjoyable to implement.

The strategy noticeably changes depending on the player count.

Take 5 is currently my favorite "nearly-pure-numbers" board game.

# BEFORE 2025-07-07

Play cards and avoid taking bull cards that show bull-head symbols.

The winner of the game is the player with the highest score at the end of a round where at least one player gets to zero points.

Players are dealt random hands and they play cards in ascending order, in one of several rows.

If they play the fifth card in a row, they take all of the cards in that row and their score gets reduces by the number of bull heads present in that acquired row.

If a player cannot play a card in ascending order, they have the choice to take any row they want.

The game is heavily luck based, however there appears to be "some" tactics/strategy that can help mitigate unlucky hands and events.

I'm not quite sure what strategies are very successful at the moment, but I got the heavy impression that the game could be enjoyed casually.

Playing this game with a more serious tone seems possible, but at that point I believe the winner would heavily be determined by luck.
Great game for 6 people in professional variant
